sections.text: Mina Park: Hi Madeline—good to see you again. Last time you mentioned you’re getting pressure from Product and Support to stop “arguing in spreadsheets” about what to fix next. I wanted to focus today on the one thing you seemed most interested in: Issue_Tracker’s prioritization layer and how it ties issue clusters back to customer value and active deals. Does that still feel like the right place to zoom in?

Madeline Cho: Hi Mina. Yes, that’s still the pain. We have Zendesk themes, Jira tickets, and then a separate doc where we try to guess impact. It’s messy. But I’m also cautious—these scoring systems can create more debate, not less.

Mina Park: Totally fair. Let me keep it concrete. Issue_Tracker ingests the reported issues from your support channels, dedupes and clusters them into “issue objects,” and then the key feature is issue_prioritization—an explainable score based on inputs you control: frequency and velocity, severity, customer tier/ARR, churn-risk flags, and segment importance. For Orchardline, the use case we talked about was: Product leadership wants ICP Tier-1 issues to outrank similar-volume noise from low-fit segments. That weighting is exactly what the scoring is designed to do.

Madeline Cho: The “inputs you control” part is where it usually breaks down. Support will argue frequency should win because they’re drowning. Sales will argue a single big logo should win. Product will argue severity or effort. Who decides, and how is it not a black box?

Mina Park: Great question—so two parts. First, the score is decomposed: you can see, per cluster, “here’s the frequency component, here’s severity, here’s ARR exposure, here’s ICP weighting, here’s any boost because it’s tied to a late-stage deal.” Second, Issue_Tracker supports different views so each team isn’t forced into one lens: Support gets an SLA-risk view, Product gets impact-versus-effort, Sales gets deal blockers, Exec gets revenue exposure. Under the hood it’s the same issue object, but the presentation is tailored to the job.

Madeline Cho: Different views sounds nice, but we still have to agree on the underlying ranking. Otherwise we’re back to “Support view says this, Sales view says that.” And honestly, we already have a prioritization meeting that’s basically negotiation.

Mina Park: Right—and I’m not claiming the tool removes organizational politics. What it does is standardize the evidence and make the debate faster. Instead of arguing over “is this common?” you see velocity and unique customer counts. Instead of “does this matter?” you see impacted ARR and which segment it hits, based on your CRM plus your fit tiers from Customer_Analyzer. The discussion becomes, “Do we want to weight ARR exposure more than frequency this quarter?” which is at least an explicit decision.

Madeline Cho: That’s exactly my worry, Mina. We don’t have stable definitions quarter to quarter. Our ICP tiers change, and Sales will push to “boost” whatever is blocking a deal. If the system keeps shifting, teams won’t trust it. They’ll keep their own lists.

Mina Park: If trust is the core risk, we’d handle it with governance. Usually we start with a baseline model—lightweight, not overly fancy—and a change log. Every time weighting changes, it’s captured and you can see what moved and why. The historical trail is one of the reasons customers use Issue_Tracker: it creates a defensible record of “this is why we prioritized X.”

Madeline Cho: But implementing governance is work. We’re a lean team. Also, we’re not currently using Customer_Analyzer—at least not in a way I’d call reliable. Our CRM data is messy. If the inputs are bad, the priority score is just… confidently wrong.

Mina Park: That’s fair. If the CRM tiers are unreliable, the score will reflect that. In those cases, some teams start with fewer inputs: frequency/velocity plus severity and a very simple tiering—like “Strategic accounts” vs “everyone else”—and then evolve. The goal isn’t perfection on day one; it’s to stop losing track of what’s real and what’s anecdotal.

Madeline Cho: We can already see frequency and severity in Zendesk. And for strategic accounts, Sales just pings Product directly anyway. I’m trying to understand what new thing we’d be paying for in month one.

Mina Park: The new thing is the standardized issue object that stays linked end-to-end—source conversations in Zendesk, the cluster, impacted customers, and the downstream Jira/Linear work. And then the prioritization score is consistent across those objects. For month one, the value is: you can open an issue cluster and immediately answer, “How many unique customers? Which tiers? Is this tied to churn flags? Is it tied to any late-stage opportunity?” without manual stitching.

Madeline Cho: The stitching is annoying, yes. But we’ve built some internal dashboards that do parts of that. They’re not perfect, but they’re “good enough.” My bigger concern is adoption. If Support doesn’t change behavior and still files tickets however they want, the clustering and dedupe won’t be clean.

Mina Park: Adoption is real. Typically we don’t ask Support to change their workflow. Issue_Tracker sits between systems, so Support keeps doing Zendesk, Engineering keeps doing Jira. We configure the ingestion and then tune clustering rules—like “treat these phrases as the same,” or “don’t merge these categories.” It’s mostly configuration and iteration rather than retraining everyone.

Madeline Cho: Configuration and iteration still means someone on my side owns it. And we don’t have a dedicated ops person. Also, if the clustering is off, it creates a lot of noise. I’ve seen dedupe tools that over-merge and then you lose nuance.

Mina Park: That’s why we keep the links to the source conversations. Even if a cluster is too broad, you can drill into the evidence. But you’re right that there’s an ownership requirement—someone needs to review clustering quality in the early weeks.

Madeline Cho: Another thing: the “boost issues blocking late-stage opportunities” piece. That’s where I expect the biggest fights. Our Sales team will want everything flagged as a deal blocker. Product will say we’re just chasing revenue and ignoring the roadmap.

Mina Park: That’s a common tension. What we suggest is limiting the boost to specific conditions: only Stage 4+ opportunities, only deals above a certain ARR, and only if there’s a clear link—like a named requirement in the opportunity notes or emails. The system can show the rationale. But if culturally your Product team doesn’t want Sales influence on prioritization, that’s a broader alignment issue.
Madeline Cho: Exactly. We’re not aligned there. We’re trying to get aligned, but I’m not sure buying a tool helps. It might actually formalize the conflict.

Mina Park: If alignment is the blocker, we can step back. The minimal pilot we discussed could be Product-only: prioritize issue clusters based on ICP tiers and severity—no Sales boosts at all. Would that be a safer starting point?

Madeline Cho: Maybe, but then I’m not sure it’s worth the budget. Leadership is asking me to reduce tool sprawl. If we buy this, we’ll need to justify why it’s better than improving our Zendesk tags and our Jira intake process.

Mina Park: Understood. Let me ask: what would have to be true for you to feel confident moving to a buying decision? Is it proof of reduced time in prioritization meetings, or fewer escalations, or something else?

Madeline Cho: Honestly? I’d need to see it working with our data without a lot of customization, and I’d need Product and Support to agree they’ll use it. I don’t have that buy-in today. And I’m not going to champion another system that becomes shelfware.

Mina Park: That’s fair. We could do a short data-backed evaluation—ingest a slice of Zendesk and map to your existing Jira projects, then show you what the clusters and prioritization would look like. But if the internal buy-in isn’t there, even a good demo won’t solve that.
Madeline Cho: Right. And I’m also heading into planning season. I don’t have capacity to run a pilot and manage the politics around it.
Mina Park: Got it. It sounds like timing and internal alignment are the biggest constraints, more than the feature set itself.

Madeline Cho: Yes. The capability is interesting, but I don’t think we can move forward right now. If we revisit after planning—maybe next quarter—when we’ve clarified how we want to prioritize, then a tool like this could make sense.

Mina Park: That makes sense. I’ll send a short recap with what a Product-only starting model could look like, plus what light governance typically entails, so you have something concrete for later discussions. And then we can pencil a check-in for next quarter if that works.
Madeline Cho: Sure. Send the recap. Let’s plan to revisit, but I can’t commit to anything beyond that.

Mina Park: Understood. Thanks for being direct, Madeline. I’ll follow up with that summary and a couple of example scoring breakdown screenshots so you can show stakeholders what “explainable” looks like.
Madeline Cho: Sounds good. Talk later.
